review.title: On Design Mining: Coevolution and Surrogate Models
review.abstract: The small body of previous work considering the design of wind farms has used arrays of turbines originally intended to operate alone, optimising the layout of homogeneous turbines essentially as an afterthought in the design process. In this paper, we consider designing wind farms composed of collaborating wind turbines. Computational intelligence is combined with rapid prototyping whereby candidate designs are physically instantiated and evaluated under fan-generated wind conditions. It is shown possible to use surrogate-assisted coevolutionary algorithms to aerodynamically optimise the potentially heterogeneous morphology of an array of 6 small scale and closely positioned vertical-axis wind turbines using the total angular kinetic energy of the array as the objective. This approach performs optimisation in the presence of complex inter-turbine wake effects and multi-directional wind flow from nearby obstacles, which is extremely difficult to achieve accurately under high fidelity computational fluid dynamics simulation. The general approach is equally applicable to the design of other forms of sustainable energy where the characteristics of the environment and/or materials involved are too difficult to accurately simulate.
histories: arXiv admin note: substantial text overlap witharXiv:1410.0547
arXiv admin note: text overlap witharXiv:1410.0547

metadata.title: On Design Mining: Coevolution and Surrogate Models

sections.text: Design Mining is the use of computer-aided intelligence techniques to iteratively search and model the attribute space of physical objects, which is evaluated directly by rapid prototyping to achieve predetermined goals. It enables the use of novel materials and processes without formal models or complex simulations. In this paper, we focus on the coevolutionary nature of the design process, when it is broken down into simultaneous sub-design threads due to the overall complexity of the task. Based on our results, the paper then describes the effective design of an arrangement of six heterogeneous vertical axis wind turbines. Keywords - 3D printing, co-evolution, shape optimization, replacement models, turbine, wind energy contact, author: Xiuu.N @ 6.023]

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In fact, most people are able to decide for themselves what they want and what they want.

sections.heading: 2 Background
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 2.1 Evolving Physical Systems
sections.text: As we have read elsewhere [55], there is a small amount of work on the evolutionary design of physical systems going directly back to the origins of the discipline [8, 51, 19, 57]. Well-known examples are robot control scenarios [45]; the evolution of vertebrate tail stiffness in floating robots [42]; adaptive antenna arrays [4]; electronic circuit design using programmable hardware [66]; product design using human-provided fitness values [28]; chemical systems [65]; unconventional computers [27]; robot evolution [22]; drug discovery [64]; functional genomics [39]; adaptive optics [63]; quantum control [36]; fermentation optimization [18]; and analytical instruments [46]; a selection of multi-objective case studies for recording surroids [40].

sections.heading: 2.2 Cooperative Coevolution and Surrogates
sections.text: In this context, it has to be said that the solution to problems that have arisen in the past is not a solution, but a solution that is capable of bringing about a solution. (...) In this case, it is an attempt to bring about a solution. (...) In this case, it is as if it is an attempt to bring about a solution that is capable of bringing about a solution. (...) In this case, it is as if it is an attempt to find a solution that is capable of bringing about a solution. (...)

sections.heading: 2.3 The NKCS Model
sections.text: Kauffman and Johnsen [38] introduced the abstract NKCS model to allow for the study of various aspects of co-evolution. In their model, an individual is represented by a genome of N (binary) genes, on which each epistatically depends on K other randomly selected genes in his genome. Thus, the elevation of K in relation to N increases epistatic linkage, thereby increasing the robustness of the fitness landscapes by increasing the number of fitness peaks overall, increasing the steepness of the sides of fitness peaks and decreasing their typical heights. Each gene is also supposed to depend on randomly selected traits in each other X species with which it interacts, increasing the number of species overall S. The adaptive movements of a species can deform the fitness landscape of its partner (s).

sections.heading: 2.4 Evolving Wind Farms
sections.text: This year, it will be able to live in a country like Germany, where it is a country, where it is a country, where it is not a country, but a country where it is a country.

sections.heading: 3 Surrogate-assisted Coevolution
sections.text: The basic coevolutionary genetic algorithm (CGA) is outlined in Algorithm 1. First, all individuals in each of the species / populations must be evaluated. As no initial fitness values are known, a random individual is selected in each of the other populations to form a global solution, but if there is a known good individual, it can be used instead. CGA then cyclizes between populations, selecting the parents via a tournament and producing offspring with mutation and / or crossover, and the offspring are then evaluated with representative members from each of the other population. At each point in evolution, each individual is assigned the maximum team fitness achieved by a team in which the team ability is the sum of the fitness values of each collaborating species.

sections.heading: 4 NKCS Experimentation
sections.text: In order to simulate this interacting system, we examine the case in which S = 6 and each species are influenced by their immediate neighbours, i.e. X = 1 for the first and sixth species and X = 2 for all others. Figure 2 illustrates the simulated topology. For all NKCS simulations performed, P = 20, N = 20, mutation probability per allele µ = 5%, and the crossover probability is 0%. When using a substitute model, the model parameters are: N-input neurons, H = 10 hidden neurons, 1 output neuron, λm = 1000, T = 50, β = 0.1. All presented results are an average of 100 experiments consisting of 10 coevolutionary runs on 10 randomly generated NKCS functions. The performance of all algorithms is represented on four different K and C values, each representing a different point in the range of inter- and alternating population dependence.

sections.heading: 4.1 Coevolution
sections.text: We start by comparing the traditional approach of partnering with the elite member in each other species (CGA-b) with conducting additional assessments (CGA-br), and examine the benefits of general learning speed from refreshing the population fitness scores as the fitness landscapes potentially shift; that is, all individuals in the other populations are reassessed in collaboration with the current elite members each time a new fit individual is found (CGA-re). As mentioned above, after Potter and De Jong [53], CEAs traditionally look at each population in turn. So, if S = 10 and each population produces one offspring per round, then 10 assessments are needed for the entire system.

sections.heading: 4.2 Surrogate-assisted Coevolution
sections.text: In this section, we compare the performance of CGA-b with the standard surrogate-supported version (SCGA-b), and compare the performance of the standard surrogate approach, in which the models are presented with only the N genes of their own species (SCGAb), with the case in which the models select all N-S partner genes (SCGA-a), and compare the standard approach of evaluating the promising nature of single-parent offspring (SCGA-b) with the search for the same number of offspring producing a single offspring (SCGA-p).

sections.heading: 5 VAWT Wind Farm Design
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 5.1 Methodology
sections.text: A single 2-stage VAWT candidate with end plates is generated here as follows: The end plates are drawn in the middle of a 35 mm diameter Cartesian mesh with a thickness of 1 mm. A central shaft 70 mm high, 1 mm thick and with a 1 mm hollow diameter is also drawn in the middle of the mesh to assemble the VAWT model for testing. The 2D profile of a single 1-stage blade is represented with 5 (x, y) coordinates on the Cartesian mesh, i.e., 10 genes, x1, y1, y1, y5. A spline is drawn from (x1, y1) to (x3, y3) as a square Bézier curve, with (x2, y2) acting as a control point. The process is then repeated from (x3, y3) to (x5, y4) as a control.

sections.text: This year, it has reached the stage where it will be able to take the lead.

referenceMentions.context: Design mining [54, 55, 56] is the use of computational intelligence techniques to iteratively search and model the attribute space of physical objects evaluated directly through rapid prototyping to meet given objectives.

Design mining [54, 55, 56] is the use of computational intelligence techniques to iteratively search and model the attribute space of physical objects evaluated directly through rapid prototyping to meet given objectives.

Design mining [54, 55, 56] is the use of computational intelligence techniques to iteratively search and model the attribute space of physical objects evaluated directly through rapid prototyping to meet given objectives.

This approach of constantly producing working prototypes from the beginning of the design process shares resemblance to agile software engineering [43]: requirements are identified at the start, even if only partially, and then corresponding tests created, which are then used to drive the design process via rapid iterations of solution creation and evaluation.

The design of modern wind farms typically begin with the blade profile optimisation of a single isolated wind turbine through the use of computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulations [68], followed by optimising the site positioning of multiple copies of the same design to minimise the negative effects of inter-turbine wake interactions [25].

Moreover, various assumptions must be made, and accurately modelling the complex inter-turbine wake interactions is an extremely challenging task where different turbulence models can have a dramatic effect on turbine performance [33].
CFD studies have also presented significant differences between results even with identical geometric and flow conditions due to the complexity of performing accurate numerical analysis [1].
In our initial pilot study we used the design mining approach to discover a pair of novel, heterogeneous vertical-axis wind turbine (VAWT) designs through cooperative coevolution [55].
Following [10], the pilot study used multi-layered perceptrons (MLPs) [59] for the surrogate modelling.

Using the data from that study, we have subsequently shown that MLPs appear a robust approach in comparison to a number of well-known techniques [56].

A selection of multiobjective case studies can be found in [40].
Examples of EAs incorporating the physical aerodynamic testing of candidate solutions include the optimisation of jet nozzles [57, 62], as well as flapping [2, 31, 48] and morphing [7] wings.

Lipson and Pollack [41] were the first to exploit the use of 3D printing in conjunction with an EA, printing mobile robots with embodied neural controllers that were evolved using a simulation of the mechanics and control.
Rieffel and Sayles’ [58] use of an interactive EA to 3D print simple shapes is particularly relevant to the work presented here.

This can be seen as somewhat akin to the minimalist approach proposed by Jakobi [34] for addressing the so-called reality gap in evolutionary robotics, although further removed from the full details of the physical system.
The first known use of cooperative coevolution considered a job-shop scheduling task [32].
Bull and Fogarty [11] subsequently presented a more general approach wherein the corresponding newly created offspring solutions from each population are partnered and evaluated.
Later, Potter and De Jong [53] introduced a round-robin approach with each population evolved in turn, which has been adopted widely.
These two partnering strategies, along with others, were compared under their round-robin approach and found to be robust across function/problem types [9].
Evaluations with the real fitness function must continue to be performed periodically otherwise the model may lead to premature convergence on local optima (see Jin [35] for an overview).

There has been very little prior work on the use of surrogates in a coevolutionary context: they have been shown capable of solving computationally expensive optimisation problems with varying degrees of epistasis more efficiently than conventional coevolutionary EAs (CEAs) through the use of radial basis functions [49] and memetic algorithms [24].

Kauffman and Johnsen [38] introduced the abstract NKCS model to enable the study of various aspects of coevolution.
Such tables are created for each species (see example in Figure 1; the reader is referred to Kauffman [37] for full details).
This tuneable model has previously been used to explore coevolutionary optimisation, particularly in the aforementioned comparison of partnering strategies [9].
As we have reviewed elsewhere [56], techniques such as EAs have been used to design wind turbine blades using CFD simulations, some in conjunction with surrogate models, e.

Most work has focused on arrays of homogeneous turbines, however wind farms of heterogeneous height have recently gained attention as a means to improve the overall power output for a given number of turbines [15, 20, 13].

[12] explored horizontal-axis wind turbine (HAWT) farms with large and small turbines positioned alternately.
[17] have demonstrated a similar potential for heterogeneous height VAWT wind farms.

[67] have performed simulations of wind farms with collocated VAWT and HAWT, showing the potential to increase the efficiency of existing HAWT wind farms by adding VAWTs.
However, floating wind farms can be deployed in deep seas where the wind resources are strongest, away from shipping lanes and wind obstructions [52].

[26] optimised HAWT platforms using a simple computational model to provide fitness scores.
As noted above, after Potter and De Jong [53], traditionally CEAs consider each population in turn.

However, at the other end of this scale each population simultaneously generates a new individual each turn, and evaluates all offspring at once [11], therefore requiring only one evaluation for the whole system.
For the case of both lower inter- and intra-population epistasis CGA-br performs better, which supports findings reported elsewhere [53, 9].

A windowed approach of using only the most recent P evaluated individuals in each species for training seemed promising in a prior experiment coevolving a pair of VAWT, however was not statistically significant in practice [56].

Bach [3] performed one of the earliest morphological studies of Savonius VAWT and found increased aerodynamic performance with a blade profile consisting of a 2/3 flattened trailing section and a larger blade overlap to reduce the effect of the central shaft, which is similar to the fourth species designs in Figures 10(d) and 12(d).
Our previous pilot study [55] considered the parallel design of two interacting objects.

Recently, 3D printing capabilities have been added to aerial robots to create flying 3D printers [30], which may eventually enable swarms of robots to rapidly create, test, and optimise designs in areas that are difficult to access.

metadata.abstractText: Design mining is the use of computational intelligence techniques to iteratively search and model the attribute space of physical objects evaluated directly through rapid prototyping to meet given objectives. It enables the exploitation of novel materials and processes without formal models or complex simulation. In this paper, we focus upon the coevolutionary nature of the design process when it is decomposed into concurrent sub-design threads due to the overall complexity of the task. Using an abstract, tuneable model of coevolution we consider strategies to sample sub-thread designs for whole system testing and how best to construct and use surrogate models within the coevolutionary scenario. Drawing on our findings, the paper then describes the effective design of an array of six heterogeneous vertical-axis wind turbines. Keywords— 3D printing, coevolution, shape optimisation, surrogate models, turbine, wind energy ∗Contact author. E-mail: richard2.preen@uwe.ac.uk 1 ar X iv :1 50 6. 08 78 1v 6 [ cs .N E ] 2 3 N ov 2 01 6 R. J. Preen and L. Bull: On Design Mining: Coevolution and Surrogate Models
